awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  High-Yield Platform Process for Fabrication of Unique Nanofiber Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to enable nanofiber integration in a wide variety of applications that were previously cost prohibitive. The technology will enable both the cost-efficient production of nanofibers at commercially acceptable rates, as well as the development of unique nanofiber materials with properties compatible with specific industry uses.  The high-capacity batteries developed as part of this effort may give rise to advancements in the energy industry enabling electricity distribution via microgrids and solar arrays, in turn supporting energy resilience, independence, and sustainability. Further, the commercialization of this technology platform for facile nanofiber production at scale may create prospects for nanofiber use across a multitude of industries, such as: textiles for fine-mesh surgical face masks and thermal regulating clothing, remediation of water and air, tissue engineering and wound care, and defense applications such as low-weight aircraft, bulletproof uniforms, and personal protective equipment for  use against chemical/biological agents.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project develops a low cost, high-throughput process to fabricate nanofibers with unique properties, enabling their integration into a variety of end applications. Traditional DC electrospinning methods have low nanofiber production rates, preventing their widespread adoption. This project develops an alternating field electrospinning (AFES) process capable of producing a wide variety of unique nanofibers at a rate thousands of times faster than existing systems. Phase I research objectives include: the characterization of different thermal settings for AFES electrospinning and studies of the impacts on material properties, the expansion of classes of materials compatible with the AFES system, and the fabrication of materials with application-specific properties.  This work will involve extensive testing and characterization of nanofibers produced under a variety of thermal process settings.  The researchers will also incorporate the nanofibers into lithium ion batteries to quantify capabilities and identify optimal silicon nanofiber characteristics for the application.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Truspin Nanomaterial Innovation is an advanced materials company developing a platform manufacturing process for the affordable production of inorganic nanofibers, including those with exotic and custom compositions. During the NSF STTR Phase I project, Truspin investigated the impact of process conditions on silica nanofiber output and quality, expanded process compatibility to include a wide assortment of new nanofiber materials, and demonstrated the technology?s ability to fabricate materials with application-specific properties. Our scalable process produces a wide variety of nanofibers with consistent outputs, infinite aspect ratios, and engineerable compositions, facilitating their physical manipulation in the construction of useful products.

Despite the broad range of potential applications for nanofibers in nearly every industry, limitations in existing fabrication methods?particularly at the industry scale?has stunted their development in the commercial space. Current methods of nanofiber production are exorbitantly expensive, and scaleup of electrospinning processes has generated inconsistent results. Our developing process overcomes these long-standing issues, providing high-throughput, well-controlled nanofiber production that opens opportunities for their adoption across a myriad of industries, such as textiles (e.g., fine-mesh surgical face masks, heat-tech clothing), remediation (water and air treatment), healthcare (tissue engineering, wound care), defense (low-weight aircraft, bulletproof uniforms, PPE against chemical/biological warfare agents), and beyond. As demonstrated during the Phase I project, our system is able to produce high-quality ceramic nanofibers at commercial scale using a novel alternating current electrospinning process. Produced nanofibers exhibited uniform size and high aspect ratios, meeting commercially relevant metrics. With a precursor flow rate exceeding 2000 mL/h, we achieved production rates higher than any direct current electrospinning system of comparable size. 

On the application engineering side, one particularly promising area of research and development undertaken during the Phase I project was the innovation of a boron nitride nanotube/silica polyceramic nanofiber, which was tested for applications in per- and polyfluoroalkyl substance (PFAS) filtration, with highly promising results. Given mounting concerns over the persistence and presence of PFAS in water resources worldwide, our nanofiber solution offers important step forward in the development of an effective, affordable PFAS filtration solution. Our application-specific work in this area also served to validate the customizability of our nanofiber production platform, indicating strong potential for novel material engineering across a variety of industries and uses.

This Phase I project established the viability of Truspin?s process for high-throughput, cost-efficient nanofiber fabrication, while also demonstrating the commercial value of this technology in a key downstream market: PFAS filtration. By enabling 1) the cost-efficient production of nanofibers at commercially acceptable rates, and 2) the development of unique nanofiber materials with properties compatible for specific industry uses, our innovation can support and expedite the adoption of nanofibers for the many long-recognized applications which have to date been prevented by manufacturing limitations.

 


Last Modified: 05/04/2023
Modified by: Anthony Brayer
